title: How to Decide What to Cook for Dinner

steps.headline: Choose a recipe with cheap ingredients if you are on a budget.
steps.description: Decide how much money you have available to spend on dinner. Pick a recipe that won’t cost you any more than this amount. Keep in mind that you might already have some ingredients that you can include as part of your “budget.” You can look at what you have, think about some possible options you could make, then estimate how much the extra ingredients would cost to help you make a decision. For example, if you only have $10 to spend on dinner and you don’t have any ingredients in the house, you could buy a pack of spaghetti and a can of tomato sauce to make a simple pasta. On the other hand, if you already have some ingredients, such as pasta and sauce, you could spend a minimal amount to buy some ground beef or garlic bread to enhance the meal.

steps.headline: Pick a recipe that you can make with what you have if you don’t want to shop.
steps.description: Look at what you have in your pantry and your fridge. Imagine several possible meals you could make out of the ingredients you have and then choose the one that sounds best.Tip: Take into account certain ingredients you have that might go bad soon. Try to use these up so they don’t go to waste. For example, if you have flour tortillas, ground beef, lettuce, tomatoes, and cheese, you could easily throw together some simple tacos.

steps.headline: Take any dietary restrictions into account when deciding what to cook.
steps.description: Rule out recipes based on things you can’t eat or that aren’t healthy for you. This will help you narrow down your options and make it easier to decide what to make for dinner. If you are cooking for anyone else in addition to yourself, make sure you know whether they have any dietary restrictions as well. For instance, if you or someone you are cooking for is allergic to peanuts, make sure nothing in the recipe may contain traces of peanut.

steps.headline: Cook something big if you want to have leftovers.
steps.description: Choose a recipe that results in large portions if you want to have leftovers for lunch or dinner the next day. Try to pick recipes that will leave you leftovers that can be used in other ways as well. For example, if you roast a whole chicken one night, then you can make chicken sandwiches with the leftovers for lunch the following day, and chicken soup with the remaining scraps the day after that.

steps.headline: Select a one-pan or one-pot recipe if you don’t feel like doing a bunch of dishes.
steps.description: Make something like one-pan chicken and rice or a casserole if you’re feeling lazy. These types of recipes usually just require basic prep work before you throw everything together in a pan and wait for it to cook. Another example of an easy one-pan recipe is a stir fry. All you have to do is cut everything up, throw it in a wok or frying pan, add some seasoning, and cook it for a few minutes.

steps.headline: Make a slow cooker recipe if you want to be hands off.
steps.description: Get a slow cooker cookbook or find some recipes online. Throw everything in the slow cooker in the morning or afternoon and it’ll be ready by dinner time. Some examples of easy slow cooker recipes are soups, stews, chili, or things like pulled pork and chicken.

methods.name: Using Apps and Websites for Inspiration

steps.headline: Browse recipe websites to find something that sounds good to you.
steps.description: Type in “recipes” on any search engine to pull some sites up or narrow down your search with other terms if you have an idea of what you want to cook. Look through lists of recipes and pick one that catches your eye. For example, if you know you want some kind of Thai food, then you can just type in “Thai food recipes” on a search engine to pull up endless options. If you are a vegan, then type in “vegan recipes.”

steps.headline: Use a “meal wheel” site to randomly select something if you have no ideas.
steps.description: There are several sites where you can spin a wheel that tells you what to eat. Use one of these if you really don’t have any preferences or ideas about what to cook for dinner and don’t know where else to start.Tip: You can pull up these types of sites by entering something like “wheel of dinner” or “recipe roulette” in a search engine. Keep in mind that the meal wheels usually don’t get too specific with recipes, but they can at least give you a category of food you can use to narrow down your choices like Italian or Mexican. You can also customise some of them if you just want to use the wheel to help you choose between recipes.

steps.headline: Use an app or site to find recipes you can cook with things you already have.
steps.description: There are many apps and sites that let you enter in the ingredients you have in your fridge and pantry and then tell you what recipes you can make with them. Find a site or a list of apps by typing in something like “find recipes with what I have” on a search engine. This is also helpful if you need to figure out how to use up a certain item before it goes bad, but you aren’t sure what you can do with the other ingredients you have on hand.

methods.name: Planning Your Meals Ahead of Time

steps.headline: Plan your meals ahead if you don’t want to decide what to cook every day.
steps.description: Look up “meal plans” on a search engine or download a meal planning app on your smartphone. Pick a weekly or monthly meal plan so you know exactly what you are going to cook for dinner each night.Tip: Many of the major recipe sites online also have meal plans. If you already know a certain site that you like the recipes from, take a look to see if they have meal plans. You can also try making your own meal plan if you want. Gather together a bunch of recipes you like and then make a calendar of which meals you will cook on which days.

steps.headline: Plan meals for multiple people if you live with your family.
steps.description: Look at the serving sizes for any recipes you plan to make and increase the quantities of ingredients if you need to cook for a partner or a family. Consult with anyone else you are going to plan meals for to make sure they are happy with the meal plan you want to use as well. For example, if you downloaded a meal plan for 1 person and you live with a significant other, then just double the ingredients in each recipe. On the other hand, if a recipe makes enough for 4 and you are only cooking for 2 and don't want any leftovers, you can cut the quantities of ingredients in half to scale it down. Make sure you know about any dietary restrictions or food dislikes that the other people you will be meal planning for have.

steps.headline: Shop ahead of time for all the ingredients you need for the next week.
steps.description: Make a shopping list of all the ingredients you need for at least the next 7 days of meals. Pick a day and time that works for you to go shopping and gather all the food you need. If you downloaded a meal plan or are using a meal planning app, they usually have an ingredient list that you can easily use as your shopping list.

steps.headline: Prepare as many ingredients as you can right after shopping.
steps.description: Chop things like vegetables ahead of time so they are ready to go when it’s time to cook. Cook any parts of your upcoming meals that you can store in the fridge for the week or the next few days. For example, you could cook a batch of tomato sauce for pasta and some chicken breasts to use in different recipes.

steps.headline: Build flexibility into your meal plans.
steps.description: Choose recipes with common ingredients to cook throughout the week. This will make it easier to prep versatile ingredients ahead of time and ensure that you don’t waste anything. For example, if you make a big batch of tomato sauce, you can use it on spaghetti one night and put it on a pizza another night.
